[h1]Game Review: Chinese Parents[/h1]

[b]Overview[/b]

Title: Chinese Parents  
Developer: Octopus Pig  
Platform: PC, Switch  
Genre: Life Simulation  
Release Date: 2018  
Price: $9.99 USD (Price may vary by region)

---

[b]Summary[/b]

"Chinese Parents" is a life simulation game that allows players to experience the unique cultural aspects of growing up in a Chinese family. While the game is humorous and entertaining, it also offers deep insights into the intricacies of Chinese culture, educational systems, and familial expectations.

---

[b]Gameplay[/b]

[b]Mechanics[/b]

In "Chinese Parents," you start as a newborn and navigate your way through various stages of life, including infancy, childhood, adolescence, and eventually adulthood. Your primary goal is to balance academics, social life, and family expectations. The game employs a turn-based system, where each turn represents a week in the life of the protagonist. 

[b]Skill Trees and Activities[/b]

You have various 'stats' like Intelligence, Creativity, and Emotional Intelligence, which can be improved by participating in activities or attending classes. There's also a unique "Face" system, representing your family's social standing, which adds an interesting dynamic to the game.

[b]Mini-Games[/b]

The game also incorporates mini-games, like tests and quizzes, to break the monotony. These are often challenging but rewarding, allowing you to gain extra points and unlock achievements.

[b]Choices and Endings[/b]

Your choices significantly affect the outcome of the game. You could end up as a successful entrepreneur, a devoted family person, or even a dropout, based on the decisions you make.

---

[b]Graphics and Sound[/b]

The game uses simple 2D graphics that are charming and easy on the eyes. The soundtrack complements the overall feel of the game, adding depth to the emotional moments.

---

[b]Cultural Insights[/b]

[i]One of the most commendable aspects of "Chinese Parents" is its authentic representation of Chinese culture. From the importance of the Gaokao (a high-stakes college entrance exam) to the nuances of inter-generational relationships, the game doesn't shy away from depicting the pressures and joys of growing up in a Chinese household.[/i]

---

[b]Pros and Cons[/b]

Pros
- Unique concept and gameplay
- Offers deep cultural insights
- Multiple endings provide high replay value
- Affordable price

Cons
- Some mechanics can get repetitive
- May not appeal to those unfamiliar with Chinese culture
- English translations can be a bit off at times

---

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]

"Chinese Parents" is an engaging, enlightening, and sometimes emotionally intense simulation game. It provides a window into a culture that many may not be familiar with, while also offering a universally relatable journey through the ups and downs of growing up.

[b][I]Rating: 8/10[/b][/i]

---

This game is highly recommended for those interested in life simulation games, cultural experiences, or simply looking for something different to play.

138678504.review:
If you can look past the somewhat shoddy English translation and localisation, the gameplay loop of Chinese Parents as a child-raising life sim is surprisingly addictive (as evidenced by my playtime). The game isn't flawless; the dating system is particularly rough around the edges, and doubly so if you're playing as a boy. (Part of me wants to believe that was intentional.) But the hunt & matching mini-game when stat building is much more satisfying than it has any right to be. And, being able to benefit from your previous playthroughs into the next generation incentivises you try to do better the next time around.

I think what I enjoy the most is how quietly self-aware the game is, and how it is both critique and comedy of this facet of growing up. If you like child-raising sim games in the vein of Princess Maker, Growing Up, and Long Live the Queen and can look past the translation quality, I'd recommend this. It's not the best game in the genre I've played, but it definitely scratches that stat-building & chasing itch.

130115957.review:
I for one love these kinds of life simulators that let you play through generations. There are so many different jobs and skills to choose from and perfect. I have spent days trying to perfect one career through each generation. The game time one can get from this game is exponential, and each playthrough is rewarding as you still gain stat bonuses even when the life turned out worse than your last one.

There are also many future spouses for your children. It's a bit weird that the date candidates have the same names as past generations, but I guess it does help when making dating guides. 

I did find an issue with parent expectations. Sometimes they would ask you to learn skills that you don't have available. During one of my playthroughs, the parents wanted their child to learn the "Modeling" skill. I looked for guides on how to get the "Modeling" skill but the only one I could find was under performing arts for male children. At the time, I was playing as a female child. I checked if I had learned "Scientific Modelling" to see if it was shortened, but I had already learned that skill. Besides this issue, it may be helpful to give a brief description of how to earn the skill that the parents want their child to learn. 

Other than that issue, I think this game is very easy to get the hang of and addicting once you do. I recommend this game to any fellow life sim fan. Just make sure you keep track of time while you play. You may be playing for longer than you expected.

118119652.review: I found Chinese Parents after logging almost 150 hours in Growing Up -- its Western successor -- so I can't help but compare the two. CP isn't as polished as GU, but what it lacks in slickness it makes up for in charm and depth of gameplay. Previous generations actually matter in this game in the form of parents' earnings and stat buffs that carry over to their children. This is a great boost to replayability instead of each generation starting as a blank slate. Some of the memes and cultural context might elude those unfamiliar with China and Chinese culture, and unlocking traits and dating as a boy can feel like a crapshoot. All told, CP and GU are both worth playing if life sims are your thing, and I'd encourage everyone who tried GU and liked it to give CP a shot.

113252716.review:
It's an excellent game! Fun and clever, and does just enough to color your character's life while letting you imagine the rest. I personally like that in a game. The two things I would like are 1. An option to date same-gender characters. I felt pretty unenthused when I the option to make friends and date opened up, 'cause I was looking at a whole load of girls. 2. A character customization system would be nice- although I understand how that would be hard to integrate into this game. I haven't played very much so far, but the feeling I get is that you might ruin the game for yourself if you play generation after generation without stopping. It's a game experience, and you should only play it when you feel like having that experience- i.e., there isn't that much variety.
Edit: Hey Hey Hey, they made some cool improvements!
They added a system where you can determine what kind of parent you're going to be to your child before the next round starts, which I LOVE. It's such a good fix to the problem of feeling like you have no control over what your character does once their round is over. Major kudos. They also made a bunch of simple but important quality-of-life improvements, like giving you a way to increase your intimacy with a character each round without wasting a ton of energy on it. There's still some stuff that needs updating, but it's cool to see a game that seems to earnestly want to incorporate user feedback.
I still wanna be gay though. I'm not too concerned with hard realism here. I like romancing boys in real life. I wanna do it in my games. Simple as that.

98868321.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 34.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

93024793.review:
Chinese Parents is an ultra-lite puzzle RPG.  There's a child, and you schedule activities to develop that child's characteristics (IQ, EQ, Constitution, Memory, Imagination, Charm and Face).  This gives you currency to play a minesweeper-like puzzle, which in turn gives you currency to buy new skills to schedule.  Rinse, lather, repeat.

The gimmick behind the game is that, after passing the final high school exam, the game loops and you start with a new kid who gets passive stat boosts based on your success.  The boost is fairly modest and is mainly determined by your career path and whether you married your high school sweetheart.  But, after playing through a few generations, the stacking gains traction and skills become easier to purchase sooner, leading to a better career later.  Just like real life.

Pros would be the simplicity (which allows you to grind out massive hours while sustaining the erosion speed of your sanity) and dialogue charm.  The lukewarm wit worked pretty well at the beginning, if I remember.  I remember being told by my mother that she regretted having me after scheduling one-too-many trips to Europe.  There are some typos and silly stuff.  I also enjoyed the jokes I told myself.  Those were good.

Cons would be the dialogue.  It never changes.  Ever!  Never ever.  And you can't skip it.  You just sit there and click and click and click and click and click and click and click and click.  You stop knowing who you are or what your reason for living is as you browse through menus or the spreadsheets you made outside of the game to ensure your taking the most efficient path to achievement completion.  You see, every single skill, that is, Every.  Single.  Skill. you acquire contains a third type of passive called a "trait" that is only unlocked through scheduled study, based on a dice roll dependent on that trait's rarity.  The final achievement of the game is to collect 100% of them.  It took me 24 generations and over 90 hours to get it, with each generation taking between 3 to 4 hours to complete.  After about 5 generations, the game loses all charm.  After 15, you speak only in tribal grunts.  This is Edge of Tomorrow: Scholastic Edition.

Would I recommend this game?  Yes.  I would recommend it TO YOU, SATAN, LORD OF THE UNDERWORLD, AS YE BRING THY DARK CARNAGE UPON THE SOULS YOU'VE CAPTURED IN YOUR UNHOLY SHRINE.  DO NOT BE FOOLED, O LORD, FOR THOUGH THIS APPEARS PURGATORIAL IN NATURE, NO EFFORTS WERE MADE TO REDUCE THE BURDEN OF REPLAY BY YOUR SERVANTS THE DEVELOPERS.  THEY MEAN ONLY TO SMITE THE FLEETING ESCAPE OF THE MORTAL'S COIL.  TAKE MY SOUL, DARK LORD, FOR I AM READY FOR DEATH.

Alright. So this is my go to game. I'm currently working on a guide/100%ing the game. I will do my best to explain this game because at a glance I'm sure it looks different than other life sims. This game is about continuity. The more you play the better the outcomes in the next generations of life. In one save you can have a lifeline of 50 generations. It takes me around 8 hours to get through one generation. You inherit the stats of your previous life and if you manage to snag a spouse/partner you get their stats to add as well. Each job/occupation has it's own unique storyline and each spouse you can take on has their own unique story line. You have 5 primary stats that you need to maintain in order to get good grades and earn face to unlock additional traits/rewards while simultaneously chasing your own dream job. You also have a cute little bubble pop mini game before the end of every day to increase your stats each color signifying another stat.

Honestly, if you're looking for a good stat simulator with unique stories to chase after in each generation and a game where choices matter to develop your child - this is a good game with a lot of content for just $9.99 USD. I mean, as I'm writing this I already have 148hrs and I'm only on generation 32.

85976968.review:
This game is honestly one of my favorite life simulator games I've ever played- The mini games are very easy to figure out, and not difficult to complete at all. 

The art style is cute but also pretty simple. There are quite a few characters you can meet through skills that you learn, and they all have a bit of a story with them- which is very nice and gives more depth to the world.

I would DEFINITELY say to first play with the tutorial to get a basic understanding of what everything does and how to play- once you complete one generation, you should be pretty good with understanding the rest.

It's pretty relaxing and you can definitely find yourself getting lost in playing it- I know that I have 😅 

The name you choose as your save is the last name of your family, so don't make anything silly or weird if that's not something you want your characters being called!

I 100% recommend this game, and hope that more games are created like this- also looking forward to any possible updates that add some new skills or dateable characters, or maybe even a second game! 🤞

-----------
Here are some tips to start out with: 💞

Time Management, Skills, Grades, and Fun: 🧭🎉📚
You dont need to study the subjects to get good grades, instead use your time slots to focus on which skill you want to be the best, on things that will give you traits, or what is needed for your goal career. Just make sure to learn the basics for all main subjects to keep a decent grade (at least a B, but an A is the one you'd want most). Make sure to have some fun activities between these- some can build your skills, can give traits, and some other great perks. You want to keep your parents happy, and keep yourself happy as well- it's all a balancing act, but pretty simple to find the rhythm of and keep with it. (Buying things from the top row of the shop can help with both mood and making parents happy, but they are limited to only 1-3 a day)

Dating: 💖
If your character is boy, it would be better not to focus on trying to date as it is much harder and takes up more of your energy than it does as a girl- if your character is a girl, just date enough to get the option to have them as an after school buddy, it will gain you relationship points with them, without needing to use your energy.

Traits: 🧬
Trying to get as many traits as possible (by repeating the same actions) is the best way to go about gaining better skills for the next generation, the game gets much easier as you build up your families skills. You get a daily boost from traits, though this boost doesn't increase every time you get the same trait- it only gives it once (but lasts forever). You can still get repeat traits, and it's better to get the best ones you know of for challenges.

It was fun at first, but after you get the hang of it, which probably takes about 2-3 playthroughs, approximately 5-6 hours, the game becomes extremely grindy and repetitive. Whether be satisfied and stop there or keep grinding is up to you.

It's called Chinese PARENTS but actually I don't feel like I'm controlling the parents. It's simply be a kid and experience the Chinese education from a new born to high school. The events are mostly true while keeps being funny and entertaining, and you'll find lots of nostalgia if you really lived through that period. That's probably the biggest pro in this game and the reason you may want to buy it.
Another good thing, which maybe the opposite of people's first impression or what they are told Chinese education to be. The career and life you'll have doesn't have anything to do with your exam scores. So The game is implying that exams and school education are not everything, and I think that's delivering a good message.

However besides that, the game itself is shallow. The core gameplay is to choose the schedule for every turn, wait for it to complete and go to the next. There are tons of things you can do which is why the game becomes extremely grindy for completionists, but whether you choose to be an artist or sportsman, it's all just click a few tasks for every turn. There are other mini games like the mine sweeper thing you'll have to do every turn, but they don't have a real impact on how you'll end up your career, especially after a few generations and when you really gets to understand the system.

So overall, still recommended, but be aware of the grind.

76692208.review:
Surprisingly awesome, Chinese Parents is a nearly perfect casual game. It's brimming with soul, and remarkably addictive. Considering its simple presentation and use of familiar concepts, it's amazing what they've done to create an immersive and interesting simulator, and it still manages to challenge with its puzzle-esque gameplay. 

The best part of this game is the atmosphere. It really encapsulates what it feels like to be growing up, with creative and sympathetic events and an excellent soundtrack. Without having to do much, it really makes you feel like a kid again, and you become invested in your stats and career goals. Likewise, there's a lot of good-natured humour about parental expectations, intergenerational habits, and childhood culture. Aside from that, the gameplay is stimulating and well-rewards one's desire for a feedback loop between unlocking desirable skills, and performing well on its "mental map" puzzles. Through all this, you're curious what kind of character you'll develop, what sort of romances they might have, and hoping that they'll receive beneficial traits from an effective schedule. 

My only major problem with the game is in its art design--it's all over the place. All the characters look like they were drawn by different people, and though it's sometimes cute and endearing, it clashes and makes the game come off as a cheaper experience. This is apparent even on the Steam art, as you can see the stark comparison between almost racist depictions of an Asian family contrasted with anime-styled art. I think they chose to keep some of these elements from an earlier build, as the facial expressions or doodles are almost iconic, even when they're of notoriously bad quality. 

I think Chinese Parents would appeal to most any type of gamer, as it's strongly reminiscent of mobile experiences; but it's a lot more than meets the eye.

75227858.review:
I love this game. It's incredibly addicting and has one of the best core gameplay loops I've seen in a while.

The premise is this: You're a child raised by Chinese parents who push you to succeed. You choose how to allocate your time from birth until the "Gaokao" a national examination you take at the end of HS (think SAT, but more serious). Do well, and you set the next generation up for success. Do poorly, and your child will struggle. You can play generation after generation endlessly, and much of what you earn in previous generations stacks with successive ones.

That mechanic is fun and rewarding. While each generation's playthrough doesn't really change, working towards the ultimate generation is enjoyable and keeps me engaged with the game.

There are a few things that I wish this game did better. It could use some QoL improvements, like the option to skip dialogue or events that you've already seen before. Some of the art could use an overhaul so it's all on the same level. It would also be nice if your previous choices contributed a bit more flavor to later generations: Marrying one of your classmates should lead to different dialogue when they're a parent, instead of just a new sprite and minor stat boosts.

But for the price, this is a great game. Definitely recommend it.

74365400.review:
Now this might just be me and my weird taste, but I absolutely love this game! The game lets you create your own Chinese family tree and you can go on for generations. This might sound very repetitive and boring, which it might be in the beginning, but I assure you it will get better. Not that the game gives you more stuff to play with, because it is basically the same procedure for each generation, but you inherit your parent's "stats". The stats are: IQ, EQ, Constitution, Imagination and Memory. When you get a child it will inherit some stats based on your career and personal progression. Now lets say your first character becomes an athlete. It will gain a boost to constitution (how much constitution you gain after each day) and some other stats based on how you lived your life. This means that your choices will effect your child's stats. Might not sound very fun, but bear with me. I once had a character whom I tried to make an athlete, but it didn't end very well. He became an athlete, just not a very successful one. This was because he had low constitution gain because of his parents lives, which means that it costs more to buy constitution based skills, and because of this you have less money to buy skills that help with your tests (which is bad) and you might not get all the skills before the game ends. However I decided to make his daughter become an athlete as well, because even though he wasn't very successful, I had still gained that constitution boost. She became a Olympic level athlete and was very successful. It was just very satisfying to see how it all came together. The same thing happened to a mathematician i made once. He wasn't very successful, but his daughter became a "Reincarnation of Gauss" and became one of the top mathematicians in the world. This will lead to a bunch of questions in your head like: "what if i focus just on IQ and all generations forward become super smart?" This is the magic of the game. I invite and encourage all of you to give it a try! 

P.S Everything more than 10 generations becomes super easy, because depending on how you played (if you tried a bunch of different careers) you will get over +100 gain per day in every stat. This makes it easier to do everything, but in a way makes it more fun too, because you get to see your demon master mind walk around getting A on every test while still because world chess, badminton, football, spelling bee champion, which I find very funny, but it doesn't take anything away from the experience

TL;DR - Don't buy it. It's broken. No patch with fix is expected.

I really enjoyed this game, yet, can't recommend it anymore. 

The game has got at least two game-breaking bugs after introducing the latest patch. The creators promised to take care of them at the beginning of 2020, but then coronavirus appeared. The studio is from China so, because of the quarantine, had to hold off for some time, which was understandable. Yet, it is the end of June when I'm writing this comment and the forum is filled with bug reports with no responses from the studio. It seems they have abandoned the project and the community. Gamers had to give themselves some tips to overcome the problem, but it's just a temporary solution, because there's no official fix.

It's a shame because this game was really good. I have already passed several generations of my family, but I guess I won't have an opportunity to write another chapter of their history anymore.

70953158.review: I don't really know why, but I'm a sucker for this game. The art direction is comfy, clean, cute, and pleasing to look at, but also oftentimes quite funny. The central backgrounds that show the scenes of life are skillfully drawn as well. The UI is perfect for this sort of game, making perfect sense and presented to the player in a satisfying way. The sound design is an absolute gem, featuring a music score loaded with character and personality, and tactile UI interaction sounds that make the game pleasing to interact with on an essential level. The gameplay itself is a fun concept, progressing a child through life until the Gaokao via a series of decision making features and a relaxing casual gem-clicking minigame. The gameplay also by its nature provides itself a high degree of replayability, even offering the player the option to go on to the next generation as a member of that family, affecting outcomes based on your last game and what your previous character was good at. Overall, Chinese Parents is a lovely game that is easy to play for hours on end, and I give it an 8/10.

It's a clicker game in disguise. It was fun for the first play-through, but only for that first play-through, because nothing new happens, each play-through is identical so it becomes quite repetitive very quickly, and the game is designed that way(by way of playing through new generations) but fails to keep it entertaining by not adding anything new except for the chance of maybe getting to play a different gender this time, and slight stat improvements from generation to generation, in terms of content it's the exact same thing though.

In the end for me, an hour or so before I quit and uninstalled it, it had turned into an absolutely brainless, mind-numbing clicker, I was just spam-clicking to go through dialog and cut-scenes and just clicking on a little bit of every subject because that's what you need to do to get a decent exam result, then repeat every 5 minutes, over and over. My eyes weren't even focused on the game anymore.

Also, considering the points above I find it very weird, almost absurd that you can't skip the seemingly endless amounts of identical dialog and cut-scenes after the first play-through, and why does it keep showing me tips meant for the first time you play-through it in all my new games, even when I explicitly select the 'Disable tutorials' option?
Not being able to skip that stuff when you've already seen it several times strongly adds to the tedium, it acts as if each time you play, you're playing for the first time... It just doesn't make any sense honestly.

You're given the illusion that you can go down very specific professions and only collect 1 or 2 certain stats that you need to go deep into that profession or skill-set by way of giving you a career goal, but in the end you have to get all stats, otherwise you'll constantly fail quests/tasks, you'll get horrible tests results, etc. The game acts as if you do not constantly practice math you'll just end up not even knowing what math is anymore after a week. If you could actually deeply pursue a certain line of skill or profession(refer to: The Sims) it could be a pretty fun game: each play through you can pursue something different and have a totally different experience with new, unique events happening based on what you're pursuing to be good at, but that's not how the game works. It is technically possible if you're okay with getting an F on every single exam and basically failing the game every time you play, but no unique events or things occurs anyway, again... it is the exact same thing over and over.

I do not see the value in it after 2 play-throughs max. If it cliques with you, that's good for you(and kinda strange that you enjoy tedium), but it doesn't for me, for me it's like re-watching the same TV-show or movie over and over and over instantly after the last watch-through. Sometimes, every few episodes or scenes you notice something you didn't last time, just some minute detail that doesn't really matter, but other than that it's the exact same thing.

The game is entirely targeted towards a Chinese audience, if you're not Chinese your chances of enjoying this game is overwhelmingly reduced, that's how it comes off to me at least. (I've even seen reviews from Chinese people saying that the tedium isn't strong enough... saying that this game doesn't make you repeat the same tasks enough, it needs more repetition)

Other dumb things:

Why is the max name length 7 characters?

The English translation is horrible(and incomplete, random things still shows up in Chinese). Considering the huge amounts of sales this game has had I think the developer can quite comfortably afford paying for a proper translation.

70605907.review:
This is easily and surprisingly one of the best and most replayable life sims I've ever played. The flow into a "new" game is really cool and rewarding, and the huge diversity and depth of paths keeps me playing more. I've learned a lot about what it's like growing up in China; there are a lot of little things that are different, and the pressure (even just of the gameplay) is overwhelming, but I really appreciate the moments where I feel total understanding and empathy for the characters, even across the cultural divide. I never would've expected it, but this game has made me tear up on a couple of its paths.

I would love more in-depth romance. I hope they spend some more time on that aspect of the game going forwards. I'm already thrilled with the huuuuge variety of endings and choices, but I'm happy to know that they're always working on more of that, too.

I'm mostly writing this because I became interested in this game and did some research about it. I learned a lot about the indie game dev scene in China, and the challenges teams like this game's developers face. I'm really happy to know that this game has been so successful there, and I hope it paves the way for more like it. I'm truly impressed with the talent and potential I'm seeing represented here.

Thanks so much for making this game! I really love it.

63969045.review:
Honestly, I'm not sure why I've put 7 hours into this game.

I think I keep expecting something to happen. There's an interesting concept somewhere in here, but it's buried beneath endless tedium. Dialog text you can't skip or speed up. Unskippable (and often irrelevant) cutscenes. Repetitive tutorials and tips--it's bizarre how a game that's meant to be played for multiple generations treats EACH generation like it's your first time playing. I don't think I've ever played a game that does this.

I can forgive the awkward English because it's inevitable that things get lost in translation. That's fine. But does the art direction get lost in translation too? I say "art direction" rather loosely. Not because the art is good or bad--it's just all over the place. It's like they hired a different artist for each character. (And I take it back: some of the art *is* bad; some of these folks are downright ghoulish.)

If the game was more fun, I could forgive all of the above. 

But it's my fault--I kept playing! Joke's on me. I guess I kept thinking there'd be more to the genetics/inheritance mechanics, or that lifestyle choices would have a more meaningful impact on how you grow and develop as a person. But as others have noted, 90% of the game comes down to a simple point-and-click mini-game. 

I don't think games should be free; developers work hard and should get paid for what they do. That being said, I'm not confident this is worth $10. If you do decide to play it, I hope you got it on a deep discount.

I started the game considering it kind of a joke but quickly realized it's anything but. The fun and light hearted nature mislead me into taking a journey into what is probably a little too real. My first game I ended up becoming a best selling author, after putting pretty much my character's entire life into it. I spent hours micromanaging and making sure I was best suited for that path, and at the end of the road I still wasn't sure. There's a lot of choices in this game, and no clear path, and that can be overwhelming very easily if you don't remember and try to stick to your goals. Especially with the pressures forced on you.

All in all, my parents wanted me to become a manager and I became a writer, and I did it by sacrificing all of my friends, working to give myself the small pleasures to let myself overwork without breaking, and never having any fun.

I started my second game deciding to just meet expectations, and go a more lighthearted route. And, in the process, some of the criticisms my original character had. I found myself asking "Where did you learn that kinda atittude?" Only to realize, I taught her that attitude. I never gave her a break, and I pushed her to succeed by sacrificing everything.

I feel like that's probably just her programmed response, but. It really gave me insight into how the mindset perpetuates itself, and as a real life writer I think I can use that in the future.

If you're looking for a reference on the feel to a Chinese character. It couldn't hurt to actually study Chinese culture and talk to some Chinese people, but this game did a pretty good job teaching me things alongside that. 

Fantastic game.

62003830.review:
I'd recommend this game if you liked sim raising games like the princess maker series. Here's a list of pros and cons at a glance. 


Pros
-Low Price
-Lots of content (especially considering the price and there's continuous update expanding the game)
-High replay value (countless endings and unlockable traits)
-Insight into a uniquely Asian style of parenting
-Pleasant art style 

Cons
-English translation needs work (sometimes it just sounds unnatural, other times it straight up does not make sense)
-Can be repetitive (However, this comes with the nature of this type of stat-raising game anyway)
-Lack of diversity/inclusivity (this game focuses on the typical life of a Chinese kid so this is understandable but this could be a big con for some so I just thought I'd mention it. There's also clear divide between the type of classes/items you can get in the shop based on your child's sex but again, that's a pretty typical reality for Asian kids)

Overall I think that while the game can be improved, if you are into sim raising games then it is well worth buying considering the low price it's marketed for.

59509531.review:
A game where I can live my dreams I would otherwise never would be able to do. I am person who sucks at studying and going big. Not because I can't, but because I don't want to. This game, however, let's me go through all of them. There are so many options and replayability is so amazing, that just wow.

There are so many different kind of mini-games, that you won't get bored, or you won't get only one thing.

You start as a child and get traits depending what you do for free time. In some sense, you probably become trait hunter soon. But you'll also decide what path you're gonna hunt with this character, while also keeping in mind to get your normal studies as high as possible.

You need to make sacrifices to get to your goal. And sometimes you do, and sometimes you don't. And once you don't, you get this bitter feeling -- but not in a way that you want to quit, quite the other way -- and you want to retry or learn way to reach the conclusion you'd want.

It's amazing game when it comes to relaxation and having it as a side, while also doing something else, such as watching tv series.

However, keep in mind that this is game that's definitely not for everyone. When I showed it to few of my friends, they immediately found it boring, while I'm thrilled and tell them what's happened to X generation boy named Y.

It's also the fact that it's a bit cruel world, showing off the parts of the world where expectations are really huge. But still true, and sometimes necessary, I actually learned few cultural things from this game.

Anyway, I might not do many reviews, but I felt that this one deserved one. Time to go and for my child to become Faker and be the world champion e-sport player ;).

59472474.review:
Why this game is great:
1. How well you do for previous characters impacts your current one, through genes, which will give you a stat boost per turn, the boost dependent on your previous characters' stats. Another example is that your character will get a certain amount of pocket money each turn depending on his/her parent's (your previous character's) job and how good s/he is at it.
2. You can play as a girl or as a boy, with things changing in some areas depending on your sex. For example, if you're a boy, you will have a different interface for friends than if you were a girl, as well as different interactions. 
3. Has great replay value. You can be a famous agent, a reincarnation of Newton, an anime film director, etc.
4. The translation sounds natural. It's very well done, and is easy to understand, no effort needed at all!

58353594.review:
Setup/Tutorial: 9/10
Strategy: 10/10, the Long Game matters
Replay Value: 11/10
Difficulty: Fairly easy, but not the easiest
Overall score: 10/10, five stars, etc. Stellar!

What an odd, addicting game! You play as a Chinese child growing up from infancy to graduating high school. Your cumulative choices add up to your score on the GaoKao, the SAT/ACT in China. Your score also determines which university you went to, whether you got the job of your dreams, and how much allowance your future child can earn. Then you get to (possibly) marry your high school sweetheart and play as your own child, from infancy to GaoKao, and on and on. Every play through becomes easier due to "genes" being passed down through each subsequent generation. You can use that boost to pursue different career paths, or to try to master one career path in particular. I would definitely recommend to anyone who likes playing cumulative completionist games. Using a guide once you are 2 or 3 generations in is a must. Good luck finding all the careers and mastering the GaoKao. You're going to need it!

55541926.review:
When I first saw Chinese Parents on steam, while tempted to buy it, being a bit partial to indie life-sims, there was also some dose of scepticism. 

The game was obviously meant to be played by the Chinese, and despite being translated to English, the game is thoroughly soaked in the Chinese culture, thus, some references may be hard to properly understand by an average European/American player (and no, having spent half of one's life reading Xianxia novels will also not allow you to really understand some references, and what I believe to be satire. Trust me, I would know). 

Then again, if you are willing to play the game without fully understanding it, or invest some of your time to to research on said references, it is one of the most enjoyable life/teen sims out there, with a good balance of stat/time management, seriousness and humour. Furthermore, it is still being updated, so after doing everything, you can still return a month later to play through a generation and see what has changed. 

Overall, while not for everybody, still an enjoyable and fun experience.

55533307.review:
I'm not sure if this game is supposed to be satire or cultural exchange...

While the premise is interesting: lead your family through generations to raise a wonderful Chinese family while trying to meet all of your parents' expectations. The game starts them out simple and then makes them more complex as the child gets older. Some can be reasonable, some can be downright impossible to achieve. Sometimes you have your own idea of where you want to go with the kid, but the parents have a complete different vision. It makes for hard choices: appease your parents or be an individual.

The game allows some choice in raising skills, but there's too much RNG for my taste. At the start of every turn you have a board which allows you to improve your skills. The boards are very randomized with no way to pick which skills you will focus on. You just have to hope that you get what you want, which does not really reflect an individual's choice to improve. You get to set a "schedule" to figure out what skill you will focus on, but it seems like you really have to take a hit in some areas to improve in others. Some made little sense to me. The tests rely on random appearances of various colored icons to form chains to make a "solution" to a problem. When you have to rely on random chance on things that really rely on more personal effort, it takes the immersion of the experience out of the game for me.

It was an interesting experience, for sure, but one that's not for me.

A pretty fun time! I checked it out because I think Chinese culture is very interesting and has been such a powerful force throughout the ages, and was very curious about this window into the mentality. Now of course it's just a game and certainly a bit silly, but I actually related a lot as a westerner both in similarities and differences; I feel I gained insight both into my own culture and that of others.

Gameplay wise, Chinese parents is fairly simple and laid back; it's certainly a casual game. I still enjoyed the almost minesweeper-like zen of the mind-map game, and the rather absurd but strangely relate-able face battles. It was probably most fun before I knew what the heck I was doing and was just picking things randomly because they sounded nice or seemed to offer some benefit. 5 generations later the powergaming is real and every move is optimized with no motion wasted.

Surprisingly though this game was pretty evocative. As a new parent I found a lot of the tiny emotional beats in this game to be almost comically impactful, and it made me think a lot about the nature of my life path and our morally festering western culture. Certainly worth the handful of moneys I paid!

Good job Devs!

55404497.review:
When I saw this game I got some strong Princess Maker vibes. So I decided to give it a go. 

/rewarded by vibes

I'm not Chinese, but I can understand the insane amount of competition and need to succeed being pressed on by your parents there. The face-off situations are clear examples of what parents go through in order to get some esteem or powerplay in their lives, simply by using their kids' progress. This is what this game stands for: to raise your kid in Chinese standards, though if I'm honest we all have those standards in some form and are all part of it.

But really, the game is fairly simple but fun as you have to level up stats for your kid (which is randomly a boy or girl) to get to a desired outcome. Focusing on every topic (math, science, sports, etc) is not advised, as we also know that in real life you should focus on one (or a few) things to get to a skillful or even master level. 

You even have a shop ingame that allows access to skills or study material for your kid to get great in. 

Other than that you have a bit of an dating/friend system in the game, but it's very flat. It definitely adds something to the game, but still looks unpolished. 

It would've been awesome if the game had any customization options in regards to yourself and/or children. The reason for this wish is that you have to play from one generation to the other. You can have an endless amount of generations but the playthroughs will all feel alike. The minigames will eventually tire out and you feel like you are in a repeat with too many texts & scenarios that you've already read/seen in previous play throughs. It is not refreshing enough to keep on doing this for xx amount of generations.

What is also a bit of a bother is that at the start of every new generation, you have to go through the same 'tutorial' steps. Somehow this cannot be disabled. 

But I have to really recommend this game. You may wonder why, but I love simulation games with a lot of stats like the Princess Maker series (available on steam) or Academagia (also on steam, though more story based). The power to mend something to your own liking and shape with certain factors, including random chance elements, can be very addicting. 

UPDATE 24/10, new patch: Tutorial skip function now available, you can skip the tutorial when creating new save file. (thank you, developers!)

7/10

54138506.review:
Remarkably complex and deceptively engrossing, Chinese Parents is a unique experience. Life Sim and visual novel, mixed with light puzzle elements, training your child to ace their Gaokao is very fun throughout. It also is a great window into Chinese culture and what childhood and teenage years are like, of course masked by several game mechanics. 

The game has several issues here and there. Although it's great the game has a translation now, and most of it is fantastically done, some parts are hit and miss. The odd typo or poor translation shows in terms of clunky sentences, or just outright bad English; some references or situations may go completely over your head because of their nuance with Eastern culture mixed with a bad translation. There's also gameplay differences between playing male and female children, and while this isn't inherently bad, playing a girl is way easier (at least in my experience) than playing a boy, particularly related to the dating mechanics, which are much more restrictive on the male side of the things. 

This being said, the game is worth it despite the rough edges. The unique experience of a really solid life sim - which are few and far between - is a joy. And the game features generations of kids, so you can move into a NG+ starting as a newborn again. Each run is always a little different, because of generational skill enhancements, family income differences, and learning the mechanics or taking a different route in a new playthrough, giving hours of additional gameplay to be had.

53988896.review:
A Chinese teenager’s review on the best Chinese-featured AVG
 The game which enjoys an “overwhelmingly positive” review is bound to be worthy of its glory, and it is also recognized by many Chinese state-owned media, like China Youth Daily and China Daily. It also interest many of my classmates, even those who doesn’t care about independent games. We enjoy it, talk about it, and reflect it. The newspaper of the game was read for many times, and my classmates feel curious and excited about it.
 As a Chinese student, the content of the game is really existing in my daily life, the pressure in preparing for Gaokao (National College Entrance Exam), the pressure from balancing satisfying parents’ expectations and chasing our dreams. Individually, the story may not happen in Guangdong, as we Cantonese don’t have that kind of lucky money culture…we prefer to give a small amount of money to every children we know. The reality is much crueler, as every action and choice is much more complex. But as the author said, he manage to compress 18 years into a few hours with fun in rounds, so the game is very signifying rather than paying attention to each details. The latter style can be explored in Tokimeki Memorial (Japan) and Gaokao Love 100 Days (China mainland), which is also excellent games. Consequently, Chinese players can recall their memories in their playing with fun and foreign players can have a look in Chinese education with fun as well. The compromise is not bad, as it successfully achieved the game’s main idea. The developer is also endeavoring to cover more aspects of Chinese education. Their determination can be proved by their progress in releasing the girl’s version and adding more details. There’s no doubt that the game is a miracle, and it will continually be miracle in the near future.
 As is known, Chinese parenting has been widely accepted as a problem in Chinese education home and abroad. There are so many Chinese parents, teachers and children taking part in it with so many critics and researchers working on it hoping to find a better solution, but only the game’s developer came up with the idea of making it into an AVG so as to draw more attention to the topic, not just for complaining, but also for finding more constructive suggestions. As the author once said, to make the game he nearly read all books of Chinese school and family he can find. Though the art resources may not be not enough, the author managed to convey his idea through the simple but impressive pictures and the fashionable words.
The method enjoy its pros and cons, and opinions rooted from Chinese culture is uneasy to be changed. Similar situation can also be seen in Japan and Korea. Of course, the system may not be the best, but evidently it is the best one available. Luckily, the Chinese authorities is also managing to perform reforms to encourage student’s all-round development. We don’t hope to follow the tracks of an overthrown chariot of Japan’s reform in the 1980s. To avoid trapped in Chinese way of thinking, we are also learning from the west.
 Additionally, as a future programmer, I am dreaming of devoting myself to the production of these independent game that reflect modern China so as to promote understanding between China and the world. 
PS: I strongly recommend you to play Gaokao Love 100 Days (English translation guaranteed) which is considered “positive” as it right reflect the puppy love of Chinese adolescents in China’s excellent public school which is generally forbidden. I’m sure that trying detailed daily life of Chinese high school students will give you a unique feeling.

Hit game Chinese Parents is a funny and insightful look at growing up in China:
PC game Chinese Parents is now in English, letting you experience life as a Chinese millennial:

The idea of “tiger parenting,” based on ideas of strict Chinese parenting, has drawn a lot of attention over the last several years. But what is it actually like to grow up with tiger parents in China? If you ever wanted to know, now you can experience it in the simulation game Chinese Parents. 

This indie title is now accessible to an international audience, with an English version of the game that has already sold hundreds of thousands of copies in China. 

This life sim, developed by Moyuwan Games, puts you in a Chinese household with tiger parents who are obsessed with your grades above everything else. You go through this journey starting as a newborn and ending at the age of 18, with the ultimate objective being to pass China’s ultra-competitive National College Entrance Examination -- commonly known as the Gaokao -- at the end of the game. 

I love Chinese Parents. In fact, I’ve written about the game twice before. But with a newly translated version available, I’ve come to realize that Chinese Parents offers far more to players than just a few hours of escapism. 

Chinese Parents shines as a great piece of interactive entertainment that offers non-Chinese players a rare glimpse into the thoughts and feelings of Chinese millennials. It sheds light on how young people in modern China have adapted to such a high-pressure environment by learning to look at their hardships through a satirical lens and roll with the punches.



This dad literally has the character ‘love’ tattooed on his arm, but he always threatens to beat up my beloved character. (Picture: Coconut Island Games)
Before I dive into the meta-commentary, let me quickly explain the game. In terms of game mechanics, Chinese Parents isn’t anything earth-shattering. It follows the tried-and-true formula of many sim games: A solid resource management game played through multiple rounds, with a variety of quirky mini games periodically popping up to prevent it from slipping into monotony. 

Chinese Parents has you work through a total of 48 rounds, building up stats like IQ, EQ or memory in each one. You can then use those stats to learn skills and meet your parents’ expectations. 

But here’s the catch: Your parents’ expectations are ridiculous. For example, besides having to pass the college entrance exam at the end, your character will have to constantly earn good grades, win elections to become class president and bag awards in talent shows. And from time to time, you have to put other kids to shame in public in order to earn face for your parents. 

It’s during the “Face Duels” with other kids that your learned skills are especially handy. These skills can be absolutely ludicrous, and depending on their absurdity, they deal varying degrees of damage to an opponent’s face (or dignity). The first to lose all their “face” loses the duel. 

For example, after you’ve taken a few English classes, your mom will flaunt that you have a “London Accent.” This might not sound all that special, but speaking the Queen’s English does sizable damage to your opponent. Better yet, if you’ve taken a few probability classes, you will then unlock a skill called “Casino Champ,” which deals even more damage than speaking like a Harry Potter character.

Your opponent also has an assortment of preposterous skills to counter you. One of these skills is literally just called “Success,” which is described as something your opponent acquires after spending all his time studying. This skill, as the name might suggest, could cost your mom a significant amount of face.



Your mom takes you out to battle other kids like you’re a Pokémon. (Picture: Coconut Island Games)
Needless to say, these battles and vaunted skills are just hyperbolic caricatures of real life. But they’re also heavily rooted in reality. 

Chinese Parents excels at treading the fine line between the real and surreal. All of the scenarios it picks manage to feel simultaneously relatable and comical. 

Another scenario in which Chinese Parents manages to evoke this absurdist feeling is in a mini game involving trying to pick the best moment to accept red packets from your relatives during Chinese New Year. The gist of the game is that you have to pretend you don’t want to receive the money -- but of course you really do -- and it then becomes a delicate dance between rejecting and receiving. 

Anyone who’s ever been in a situation like this will immediately recognize the feeling evoked here. While this tradition of push-and-pull can actually be very annoying in real life, the gamified version in Chinese Parents is much more enjoyable. 

Mini games like Face Duels and Red Packet Battles attest to the ingenuity of Chinese Parents. The developers were able to find the most comical aspects of growing up in China and the most effective way of gamifying these practices or traditions. 

As a game reviewer, I appreciate when a game’s mechanics feel more inspired by real life rather than forced. And as a Chinese millennial, I find the developers’ absurdist outlook empowering.



In order to get the red packet, you have to tap your space bar to keep the smiley face within the highlighted range until the time runs out. (Picture: Coconut Island Games)
By now you’re probably wondering how the English translation relates to a Western audience. There’s certainly a lot of juicy nuance lost in translation, but the game still offers a competent translation of something that might be difficult for foreign audiences to relate to. 

The translation tries to be both idiomatic and loyal to the source text, which isn’t an easy task. But while the game largely succeeds at expressing its self-aware humor in English, it still feels a little too indie or amateur at times, including blatant typos and errors that could have been caught with some professional proofreading.

These flaws are forgivable, though, thanks to the developers’ delightful sarcasm. Chinese Parents also has a unique style. The game’s art is at once adorable, kitsch, doodly and meme-littered. The style is effective at starting players off with low expectations but slowly winning them over with candor and authenticity.



The game has a lot of replay value because when you finish, your character gives birth to another potato-looking baby with a better chance at success than your first-generation character. (Picture: Coconut Island Games)
Best of all, no matter how over-the-top the comedy in Chinese Parents might seem, the game’s protagonist always feels relatable and likable. No matter how you play the character, whether as an overachiever or a bottom-dweller, he or she always retains a self-deprecating sense of humor. 

Many Chinese gamers would describe Chinese Parents as a “diaosi” game. The term diaosi started as derogatory internet slang but evolved into a popular self-ascribed title for anyone who considers themselves “a lovable loser.”

All things considered, Chinese Parents is a beautifully crafted satire that takes you into the hearts of Chinese millennials. Behind the veneer of sarcasm is a level of introspectiveness that highlights the feelings of both helplessness and amusement in a high-pressure society that prizes deference and dignity above all else. 

With China increasingly trying to cover up its vulnerabilities and look unassailable to the rest of the world, Chinese Parents gets you an inside look, letting you experience China as just another lovable loser.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND

Lastly I think it would be cool if there were permanent changes you could make to a game save over generations. Like if there were skills/careers that you could unlock over generations, or if you could build on a career path over multiple generations. 

Overall I think this is a game with a lot of potential that was made as a fun little project. With a few tweaks and some more content, I think this could be a genuinely good game. I love getting these interesting and often funny insights into modern Chinese culture! This is a point and click game, though it can get complex. You control the choices of a kid from birth to early adulthood, at which point you switch to controlling that character's baby (with certain bonuses to stats depending on how well you did with the last gen). I'm really enjoying this game and there are far less issues with the English than I expected; apart from occasional errors, I suspect there are a few things that could be translated correctly but only by somebody with a strong understanding of both cultures. The only real cons I've found are:

The dating styles are completely different for boys and girls (this affects who your kid marries), which doesn't make much sense outside of the difference in numbers of men and women in China

How repetitive each gen can be, especially because you tend to have certain skills more easily gained because of choices in the first generation.

It's a cheap and fun casual game I'd recommend, especially while the sale is on.

Its a nice, even if rather repetitive, game. At the beginning, and probably in the first 3-5 generation, you will be lucky to even get a decent final score, but once you pass those first grinding stages it picks up fast (especially once you start earning +100 stat points per turn). At that point, you will have to choose whether to go on grinding all the different traits and endings or give this game a big thanks for the time spent and move on.
The mechanics are very simple, but can be frustrating to those who hate grinding games (and this IS a major such game since stats, wisdom and energy management decide just how far you can go).
The game gets VERY repetitive after a few rounds since there is hardly much choice you can take at the start and, if you aren't aiming at specific traits or endings later, it isn't easy deviating too much if you want a decent ending score at all.
Music and sounds are ok, but the game is not affected even if you play it on mute.
The graphics involve ALOT of memes and weirdness that repeats itself so expect yourself to do alot of text-skipping, especially from the 4th or 5th gen since the main plot doesn't change no matter the choices.

Overall I would say this is a nice casual game to pass the time, but I would mostly recommend it to those who don't get bored from repeat task, or those among us who can't leave a game without getting all the achievements in it (and this one.. will take time....... freaking traits.......)

An interesting, albeit shallow, look into the lives of Chinese children. 

Gameplay: Decent enough to pull a handful of hours from you, but it is very much a point-and-click type of game.

Sound: I muted it. That is not to say that it is bad, I was always watching something else whilst playing this.

Graphics: perfectly suited for the game.

Translation: Serviceable. You will understand the vast majority of what is happening, but there are one or two outright confusing sentences (that I have come across). The grammar is surprisingly okay, though some of the more subtle parts of English grammar are missed.

Replayability: If you like the game the replayability is massive. There are over a dozen career paths to aim for and a lot of 'skits' to see.

Overall: The game is good and is definitely worth the price. I did find it slightly depressing regarding the way Chinese parents treat their children (assuming this is a realistic portrayal of the average Chinese family). And if you are a girl? Well, your parents are more concerned that you marry a well rather than receive a decent education. Also, the Gaokao is absolutely moronic. One test determines your WHOLE future?! Insanity. 

Rating: 7/10 - Recommended for all.

A superb raising sim - I've been looking for something *that* good since Princess Maker 2.

The game is perfectly designed, with all the small but meaningful choices leading to multiple endings. Numerous activities are hidden behind simple yet fun mini-games that are interesting in their own way, still short enough not to distract from the main game. All the key elements - like contests, children rivalry, dating, special events, balance of training vs. entertainment vs. work, etc. - are there, some with a nice twist. The feeling of raising child is almost real, and at the same time the game is very positive and sympathetic. Generations and developing of family traits is an added bonus.

Perhaps this will get repetitive to me after some time, but since this is a casual game, and possible endings are dozens (maybe hundreds?) I don't believe this is going to happen anytime soon.

Somos un niño o niña criado por unos padres chinos estereotizados, osea, unos tremendos asquerosos, en concreto mi padre era un borracho machista que me metia drogas en el biberon para no aguantarme y mi madre una maruja machista explotadora que me espiaba el diario, me prohibia todo y me obligaba a estudiar 24h para aprobar el maldito Gaokao, que es el objetivo del juego.

El juego mezcla conceptos de princess maker de ir dandole unos estudios, trabajos y entretenimientos para ir subiendo stats e ir escalando y desbloqueando nuevos, a la vez que nuestros padres nos ponen unas espectativas (POR LAS NUBES) que hay que cumplir para que esten contentos, a la vez que nuestra madre tiene batallas RPG con otras madres para pollagordear de que hijo es mejor y mientras cosas aleatorias suceden una y otra vez.

51415149.review:
I bought it as a joke, but it turned out to be a lot more interesting than I thought it would be. I was playing it with a friend who grew up in a Chinese household, and she made me stop so she could take screenshots to send to her siblings because it was "too real".

So the things that stood out to me:
[list]
[*] The gameplay has about the right amount of strategy + feedback loop to keep you playing a while, having subsequent generations be improved as you gain more traits encourages a bit of variety in your approach each time.

[*] The English translation is livable. It reads exactly like how my father who is a first generation Chinese-American immigrant would write. He has lived in the US for over 40 years and worked as a University professor so had a great deal of opportunity to practice his writing, but it still ends up more like this translation than what a native speaker would write. The most common mistakes seem to be incorrect mixing of pluralization/tense and mixed up homonyms. In the end you can read it easily enough, and it's much better than a machine translation.

[*] There really needs to be a way to speed up the text, especially on multiple play-throughs

[*] The limitation on name length should be raised for the English translation, seeing as if we want to put western names they tend to have a lot more characters

[*] Even after several generations I still don't understand how the literature essays work
[/list]

All in all, I spent a lot of time trying to get into the best University while enduring endless criticism and judgement. Only to inflict the same torture on the next generation because you can't help but become part of the system.

51404443.review:
video review: https://youtu.be/RGa6XNzj_9U

written review:

Chinese Parents is a life simulation game most similar to Princess Maker. It's a game where you take control of your character for the first 18 years of their life. You carefully manage your abilities, your parents expectations, friendships, romances and your stress level. There are over 100 endings and each time you achieve one, you can start over as your son or daughter. Your gender is random. 

Pros:

- large variety in choices and endings make for many different playthroughs. 

- is often relatable even for a western country. While I grew up in a less strict environment, the high school ending exams were our rite of passage in its own and this game does remind me quite a lot of that. 

- every playthrough will take an average of about 2.5 to 3 hours, meaning for the price that you'll pay, you'll likely get a lot of time out of it.

Cons:

- luck plays a large part in it. Luck also plays a large part in life, however you likely won't end up in the best place without some luck on your side. 

- there are several different mini games in the game, however the one that will be used the most will be the stats raising game. You may get bored of it.

- tutorials repeat every time you play.

Overall, I highly recommend Chinese Parents. I thank the developer so much for localising it and bringing it to the west as not even all Princess Maker games are localised. Good child raising simulators are few and far in between, so I highly encourage to grab this one!

51393680.review:
This game is a lot better than I expected.

If you're familiar with Princess Maker, it's like that except without the adult overtones and with the ability to carry attributes over to your next character. 

If you're not familiar with Princess Maker... basically you start as a baby and have to build your stats over time in order to perform successfully on the gaokao, which is comparable to the SAT's. These stats are built up with a whole bunch of different minigames. It's not just being good at a minigame though, you need to be good at managing your time so that you're building up in the right areas.

You're not just min/maxing, either. You also have to meet your parents expectations at different times of your life, so sometimes you need to get out of min/max mode in order to hit a goal.

Having knowledge of Chinese culture helps, but I certainly think you would understand what is going on without that background. I guess... just keep in mind that the idea of face and status is very important. Being able to show off and look better than the next person. That stuff sounds shallow when looking at it with Western ideals but it is more important in China. I think you could get some impression of Chinese culture here and maybe learn something about it, but you wouldn't learn a whole lot. Don't buy it for that, buy it because it is a good Princess Maker style game.

You wouldn't be disappointed paying full price for this.

50345353.review:
It's difficult for me to review this game because it's a target specific game aiming at the Chinese Users. It's like reviewing a religion or something. If you're not part of the Chinese main/sub culture. Chances are your enjoyment of the game will be greatly limited. Because this game rely heavily on that resonance of the Chinese culture. That [b]"ah hah"[/b] moment when you recognize something you see in game as something you've personally experienced. Strip that away and the game itself is actually pretty complex but repetitive.

Basically, you playing a kid, who miraculously have the freedom to organize his schedule from birth (which, if I may add, is a freedom no human child on Earth have). And every round you can do this, sarcastic quotation mark [i]'puzzle'[/i], where you click a bunch of color pieces to gain some stats. And then you get to assign 6 task that you'll do this round, each of which will grants you additional stats, some of which have some negative penalty (i.e: leisure activity usually causes your parents to be disappointed at you). Your main goal is to get your stat as high as possible given the time constraint so that at the end of the generation, the kid can find a good job and a good husband/wife (as far as I can tell after 2 generation, homosexuality isn't an option yet).

My main problem with this game is that firstly, sometimes I feel that my control with this game is rather loose. I can actively select which stats I want to gain by popping more said type of puzzle pieces each round and assigning more relevant task. But there is a lot of stuff that is completely random as well. Each round there is a few random event that will either reward you or punish you at random. And whether or not I gain an active skill from practicing a task is also random as well. Once a classmate got hurt and somehow I lost some constitution and I'm just like, why am I losing stats for something that happened to my classmate? Seriously, if you don't have the mindsets to struggle through this kind of grinding, just stay away from this game, because this game gets really repetitive really fast and you're constantly struggle to get your stat up to the point where you'll get a good ending. And then you start all over again with a new kid.

TL;DR: This game is aimed at the Chinese audience. As a Taiwanese currently resides in Canada, I can enjoy this game to some degree. But I honestly can't imagine anyone who isn't Chinese enjoying this game. If the developers are reading this, I hope that more mini games gets added to this game. i.e: more variety of mini game to increase stat rather than just one single game. And more mini game for other activity as well. Maybe even mini game that will give you positive outcome in random event instead of just randomly punishing a player just for the RNG.

49150935.review:
A review for curious non-Chinese speakers:

This is a turn-based game in which the aim is to guide a Chinese kid from birth all the way to the dreaded College Entrance Exam. Along the way, you'll have to decide which personal attributes to develop (through playing a light-puzzle game), decide what to study, who to hang out with, and try to balance the expectations of your parents with your own happiness (slack off too much and you'll provoke their ire, study too hard and you could suffer a nervous breakdown).

The variety of fun little mini-games keeps things from becoming too repetitive. I especially enjoyed the 面子对决 (face/pride battle) sub-game, where a neighbour or relative makes caustic remarks about you in order to make your mother "lose face". You have to defend yourself by boasting about your son or daughter's talents. Whoever has the most hit points left at the end wins the battle.

Overall, this game is a satirical, but affectionate, look at Chinese childhood, so I'm not surprised by how popular it has been with Chinese gamers. You're probably wondering by now, is this worth buying for non-speakers of Chinese? The answer, unfortunately, is no. Being a largely text-based game, I can't see anyone without at least a foundation in Chinese getting much out of it. For those that can read a little, I have written a basic tutorial here to get you started:

https://www.chinese-forums.com/forums/topic/57941-chinese-game-review-chinese-parents-%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD%E5%BC%8F%E5%AE%B6%E9%95%BF/?tab=comments#comment-449690

I think it's a shame that this game is currently inaccessible to non-speakers of Chinese, as it is a lot of fun and would help foreign people develop a greater understanding of everyday Chinese life and culture. If the developers are looking to do an English translation and require any help from a native speaker, I'll be happy to help.

For non-Chinese players:

This is a game that more like a feast for Chinese people only. It contains so many 'netas' or, memes exclusively belonging to the Chinese. Even if you can master mandarin (which I think is very difficult), you may not enjoy the game either as it requires you to have a very deep understanding about Chinese culture, education system, societal problems, and concerns, etc.

For me, I think the game is worth the price only because A) it is cheap and B) it is a meme compilation and reflects my personal real life. The game mechanism is still somewhat simple and lame. It is not like that you are enjoying life as a kid but actually you are forced into sections of small puzzles that can be boring over time. In other words, the game is even more tedious than the real life as time passes. Hence, you are very likely to get bored after two or three saves.

However, the devs are great in listening to the community and do have patches every two and three days. Now it is near the Spring Festival in China (something like Christmas), but they are still releasing fixes and updates.

So in conclusion, I would not recommend to non-Chinese players. but if you really want to play this and know how Chinese kids grow up in reality anyway, I am glad to help by maybe doing some translation for you.

Update: about the English version of the game

I think currently there are no plans for official English because there are only four people working on this indie game. Bugs & new features are prioritized rather than a translation. Even if there's a translation, I think extra captions have to be added for a detailed explanation of culture, or non-Chinese players would really have no idea about what is going on at all.

2019年2月8日追加评论：
《中国式家长》出了女儿版，于是我去重新开了个新档。通关后，还是有蛮多想说的。

首先，在我看来，这是个"完美"存档。高中三年女主一直和同学"朱煜明"(计算机大大，可爱的男孩子2333)谈着恋爱。并且最后两人结婚在一起了。。。女主也非常喜欢计算机，高中三年和男主既有情感交流，也有技术交流。。并且最后女主也如愿去BAT做算法去了。

虽说是"养女儿"，但又有些下意识的代入自己。(不然女主也不会做CS去了吧23333)。

以及游戏还是挺写实的，各种意义上。不管是女主的奶奶，还是爸妈，多少都发表过类似于"女孩子不该学计算机，这是男孩子干的"，"女孩子以后总得嫁人，学校好学历高也没用"一类型言论。。。

想到从小到大，来自于小学初中的老师，来自于长辈的口中，不乏类似于"女孩子读书后劲差"，"女孩子不适合理工科"一类言论。(事实上，我的初中班主任，就经常把这类话挂嘴边)

想到以前有人讨论，为什么mtf跨性别，为什么药娘里，几乎绝大多数都是学理工科的。。。原因很简单啊，因为mtf，从小都是被当做男孩子，来培养和教育的啊。。。

在mtf的成长过程中，当表露出自己喜欢理工，喜欢机械，喜欢计算机这类兴趣时。不仅仅不会像有些女孩子一样，被长辈师长同学所"劝退"，反而可能会被鼓励。。。

我从来不认为，男性和女性，在性格、爱好、特长、三观等等，天生有着"本质的差异"。而至于为什么不管国内国外，STEM相关的理工大类里，总的说来，女性数量总是明显少于男性。更多的还是社会因素等等吧。

以及只要玩跟青春、校园有关的"模拟人生"一类的时候。。。总会有些比较复杂的情绪。不过这也难怪啦。毕竟，对于跨性别而言，校园和青春，应该多少都是"不可解"的存在。。。

毕竟知道，自己喜欢的人，暗恋的人，根本就不可能喜欢上自己。。。事实上，根本连恋爱和表白的身份都没有吧。嘛，人生就是如此啦。各种"不可解"。

不管怎样的青春，都是青春。不管怎样的人生，都是人生吧。大体如此。



-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Wasn't expecting much and didn't get much on the first release. Worths its price and nothing more, basically only the first two generations make sense.
The stories this game is trying to tell is quite vast, and actually reflects a rather large portion of Chinese society and culture. I'm really not expecting it to express it reasonably across the lifestyle of all classes, since the team only consists of a limited number of people from one or two type of families, and you can only have so much of imagination and so much of resource to put into this game. It's a barrier that's not easy to cross.
That being said, today I'm glad to see the dev team is still updating this, having the enthusiasm to take this game to what it potentially might become, and maybe they could finally build an immersive gameplay that lasts tens of hours, or even more!

What a fasinating game and I just could not even close it after starting the first round. "Tiger Mom" is the theme of the game and the game is truely a simulator of a typical modern chinese family. It cruelly reflects an inevitable game -- GaoKao (college entrance exam), that you may not want to play -- though it is "all" your life in the game. The "rest of your life" in the game, which is the the final result for you baby in game, though, is not even directly associate to your college entrance exam score. Actually, your inherited wealth and gifts from your last generation in the game affects more.

Honestly, when playing this game, I was almost brought back to my childhood. Espeically in part that how the game vivify the peer pressure I used to endure. When I finished the first round, after studying extremely hard in the game-- almost abandon all the social activity and learn nothing apart from the main course-- I was admitted to an average univeristy and fianlly become an algorithm engineer in the end.
